comment.author: 37718677955@N01
comment._content: Love this image... and I can't quite put into words why exactly.  It feels like it could have been posed yesterday for some overly presumptuous band promo-photo.  The cliche props... everyone looking slightly away from the camera but in their own "lost" kind of way.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: This photograph is feintly captioned "LANE COVE 1896" perhaps it may be 1895. The beer bottles have labels "The Royal Ale" and "Bernard's Edinburgh - India Pale Ale" enclosing a photograph of His Royal Highness The Prince of Wales, later to be His Majesty Edward VII. The chap on the left appears to have "LOO-E" written on the band of his hat. Using the zoom function at the Persistent URL, I daresay the man at the far right in this photograph is the same man at the far right in the boat here: www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3072377799/

comment.author: 8822983@N08
comment._content: Well done Lifeasdaddy, that zoom fn on the persistent URL is brilliant, here I was trying to decipher the print with a magnifying glass! www.archiveshub.ac.uk/apr02.shtml The original Looe of course is a fishing port in Cornwall, and given the location and slightly nautical headgear, could it be the name of their boat?

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...

comment._content: I did not even know there is an original Looe.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Could "Loo-e" (on the left) be the affectionate nickname of Louis Abrahams (1852-1903), one of the founders of the Heidelberg School with Tom (Bulldog) Roberts, Arthur (Smike) Streeton, Frederick (Prof) McCubbin etc? His family business was in cigars, and he supplied wooden cigar box lids to paint on for the 9 x 5 Impression Exhibition of 1889. In his hand -- a cigar! judaica.library.usyd.edu.au/histories/artists.html I believe we are looking at the Heidelberg School members, friends and families in these photos. GOLLY!

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
beachcomberaustralia - you are making some very good points here. 
If you are right, these are looking like some very significant pics.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
lifeasdaddy - thanks for your encouragement.  If my 'hunch' is right with this and other pictures, it is really very exciting.  I am having great fun finding connections, but I am not an expert in art, art history, or photography.  I would appreciate any help from yourself or anyone with any knowledge of the Heidelberg School who can identify these characters.

If I am completely wrong with my conclusions, the pictures are still terrific in their own right.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Enlarge the face of the man on the right using the Persistent URL and compare with this: www.artistsfootsteps.com/html/Streeton_biography.htm Is that Arthur Streeton aged about 29 (he was born in 1867; this photo is dated 1896) ?

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: @beachcomberaustralia - Yes, this is a great photograph regardless. Now, is it Louis Abrahams (L) and Arthur Streeton (R)? I agree with you that the portrait of Streeton at www.artistsfootsteps.com/html/Streeton_biography.htm looks mighty like th chap on the right in this photograph. It would be good to find more and similar youthful portrait photographs or either man for comparison. First I would check Picture Australia for "Louis Abrahams portrait" and "Arthur Streeton portrait" www.pictureaustralia.org/ I can find none of Abrahams there, and several of Streeton. the Streeton portraits are mainly of an older version, so difficult to use for comparison in this case. Google images is often our friend in such a search. Streeton: images.google.com/images?hl=en&q=Arthur+Streeton+port... which yields this one for example, the same as the one you have already discovered except clearer and reversed: www.outdoorpainting.com/History/Streeton.php and this outstanding portrait of Streeton from the National Portrait Gallery, however in profile: www.portrait.gov.au/site/collection_info.php?searchtype=b... A search for a photograph of Louis Abrahams is proving fruitless thus far. He was painted in distant profile by Tom Roberts, but it's not helpful ( The Artist's Camp www.ngv.vic.gov.au/collection/pub/itemDetail?artworkID=19951 there you see Frederick McCubbin seated while Louis Abrahams leans over him. ) We can approach this from another angle. What if we try to confirm that Louis Abrahams and Arthur Streeton were in Lane Cove during 1895 or 1896?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Good stuff, lifeasdaddy - I cannot find a clear picture of Louis Abrahams either. Here he is with a beard: www.artistsfootsteps.com/html/McCubbin_downonhisluck.htm How about this for a match for the man in front lying down? www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=385890&... And this: www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=385710&... Also this; notice the man in the centre: www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=386860&...

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: beachcomberaustralia - The match for the man infront lying down you mention: www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=385890&... is very good. Certainly the same man. Also, the portrait at that link has been retouched at the moustache are and the sideburn to add grey hair. Second match - I'm not sure. Third match - yes, you are right again. Returning tot he question of Louis Abrahams: sometimes you have to contact a real live person to find an answer. His great-grandchildren sold a Frederick McCubbin painting "Sawing Timber" at auction throught Christie's in 2007: www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=... Apparently they are in Britain. (http://www.smh.com.au/news/arts/nude-ned-is-sure-to-get-a-nod/2007/12/10/1197135369085.html ) I'm sending an email to the Christie's representative in Australia, Mr. Ronan Sulich, to see if he could make inquiry with the family about possibily identifying the man at left in this photograph.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Great idea lifeasdaddy - hope it is fruitful. Do you know of any McCubbins to ask about this family? - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3251833363/

comment._content:

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: There is another interesteing pic in the Phillips collection, not yet on Flickr, showing three men harbourside. Middle man could be McCubbin - but better comparison photographs of McCubbin are needed. See here: www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=386462&... I'm not even sure if McCubbin can be placed in Sydney or New South Wales during relevant periods.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Lifeasdaddy, the excellent artistsfootsteps site is very helpful in identifying Abrahams and McCubbin as the models in Tom Roberts' painting - www.artistsfootsteps.com/html/Roberts_artistscamp.htm . BUT (and it's a big but), what if the author has the characters reversed? I think it is Abrahams seated, looking similar to the 'Loo-e' in this photo, and the 'middle man' you mention above. McCubbin is the one leaning over with a beard as in most pictures I am finding of him. McCubbin seemed to be fairly settled in Melbourne in the 1890s with family and work commitments (see www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3251833363/). All the others flitted around between Sydney, Melbourne, Tasmania, England and France, escaping from the depression, and scratching commissions wherever they could. The subjects did not all have to be in Sydney or New South Wales; the photographer could have been the traveller, but he knew a lot of friends who recur in these photographs in different places, groups, costumes etc. My 'hunch' is still that Tom Roberts is the photographer. He had photographic experience; the portraits are composed and posed with an artist's eye even though they are outdoors 'plein air' and natural light - several remind me of French impressionist paintings; several are of very strikingly similar views to Tom Roberts' own paintings, as well as Arthur Streeton's; many are of personal friends, not done for commercial gain, but are of incredible quality. And he does not appear in the photos because he is behind the camera. Could it be that these picture were meant as studies for paintings? Tom Roberts moved around all over the place - a box of 193 glass negatives would be easier to leave in the care of a friend in Sydney, possibly Arthur Phillips. All a huge assumption, I know - more positive matches of faces and evidence of artist's materials is required. HELP AND OPINIONS PLEASE ANYONE!! If all this is wrong, at least they are great photos in their own right!

comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: This week is was speaking to a photography curator, who while NOT having seen any of these photographs in the Phillips glass plate negative collection, did say that due to the rising phemonomenon of photography from 1880 onwards it was actually common for Australian painters of the age to use photography as an aid to their work.
